Secures the HBP cable bundle to the leading edge of the X-Stage so that all motion-induced stress is removed from the HBP connector.
Relatively light-weight.  Self-attaching, with optional securing screwhole.

Clip can be removed from HBP before fully cooled and squeezed slightly for tighter grip if needed.
Could be used in other edge locations.

comments.text:
I got it to work briefly by increasing the print tolerance a little, but it failed soon after as the outer ring split at the logo. A reinforced outer rim even as a separate print to press fit around the bearing would be a fix to it though. It took a while to get everything turning but it did turn freely before it broke. I'd recomend always printing on a raft with these bearings to make freeing them up easier.
I hope that's been a little help if you try anything similar again.
comments.author: gufoe

comments.text:
Thank you! I've tried changing a little the parameters, and I had the same outcome: it broke on the logo.
Anyway, I found that printing at very low temperatures (175-180) the gears tend to detach better.

description.text: This fan duct suits my replacement carriages, mk5 extruder and a E3D hot end. Due to the bulk of the E3D hot end, there is no room for a traditional front mount fan duct. Due to the added length, however, room is available under the the extruder carriage to mount a 30 x 5 mm fan.

This can only be used my my replacement Solidoodle carriages, specifically the updated v2 version. If you already have a previous version fitted, the only part that is a must for this is the centre_front piece.  
Print fan duct as is, no support needed.  
Fan attaches to duct with 2 x M3 x 10mm screws.  
Duct attaches underneath carriage with 2 x M3 x 25mm screws. Nut traps are built into the centre_front piece of the carriage if you would like to secure it very tightly.  
Dimensions in mm.

comments.author: wackyvorlon

comments.text: It's not aimed at the hot end, its aimed just below it to cool the extruded filament the instant it's come out of the nozzle onto your print, to stop drooping/swelling and deforming of your prints.  Especially required for small layers that dont get time to cool before the next layer is placed on top...  Makes the prints much cleaner and accurate.

title: Spool Holder w/ Printed Bearings and Filament Clip

description.text:
This is a great way to help reduce filament tension. Using some tweaked printed bearings from emmet's http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53451, this filament holder should help eliminate friction and tension on your filament, giving you better prints! I modified the bearings to have a smooth inner bore as well as having a 50mm outer diameter. This matches the hole size of the Type A Machine filament spools almost perfectly. Required materials:
5/16" wooden dowel
Adhesive foam or similar to serve as a spool block

Print 2x bearing.stl and 1x SpoolHolder3.stl.  
Fit the bearings over a 5/16" wooden dowel (available at any Fred Meyer or similar).  If your tolerances match mine, it should be a very snug fit.  
Next, fit the dowel into the spool holder piece so that there is a space between the bearing and the spool holder.  
Finally, put some foam or similar on the edge of the inner bearing to stop the spool from resting against the spool holder.  This cuts down on friction.  (I couldn't figure out how to modify the bearing in FreeCAD to have a ring on one end.  It just kept on complaining about working with meshes.  : /)  
All items were printed without support on a TAM Series 1 Printer.  If you are unable to print the bearings correctly, you can modify the "Inset Surface" or similar in your slicer to get things to fit properly.

title: Ball Bearing Filament Guide for Replicator 1 / CTC / FlashForge

description.text:
I was looking for a simple and effective filament guide for my CTC printer, since it did not come with anything to prevent the filament from getting stuck in moving parts or on the printer casing.

The circular guide provides low friction for extreme movements of the print head and the ball bearing lets the filament slide smoothly back and forth while printing.

In addition to the printed one piece filament guide you will need one ball bearing [15x10x4 / standard RC car size] and three zip ties to fix the guide to the printer.

I printed the PLA part with 10% infill to keep it flexible enough to bend it open and slip the bearing in.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.27 (or anything between 0.2-0.3)

Infill:

10-20%

Bend the guide open and slip the bearing in place. Use a zip tie on the dedicated spot below to hold the bearing securely in place.

Use two zip ties to fix the guide to the existing slots next to the main cable harness on the back of the printer.

I remixed slavikk's adorable T-rex model in Voronoi style using Meshmixer. The patterned mesh has been fully repaired and remeshed, so there shouldn't be any manifold or gap issues (except the intentional ones!) once he's sliced. There are two .stl files - one includes the support structures (generated for a 50deg threshold) and one without supports.

This model (like most Voronoi's) has fairly aggressive overhangs both externally and inside the model, so I'd suggest using a dissolvable material, like PVA, for the supports. Included in the gallery is the overhang analysis with an angle threshold of 50, and the resulting supports generated in Meshmixer, to give you an idea of what the support structure will look like if you want to try printing entirely in PLA or ABS and removing the supports by hand (which might be possible with a scaled up print). This model should work great with any powder based printers as well, for those of you that may have access to one!

I haven't printed him yet, but stay tuned for print pictures!

Printer Brand:

Airwolf 3D

Printer:

AW3D HD

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

40%

Vapor Polishing

If you print him in ABS, be careful if you want to vapor polish! Parts where the voronoi pattern is dense (feet, eyes) will not polish as quickly as the parts where it is fairly sparse (head, tail, etc), so keep an eye on it to make sure it doesn't dissolve parts of the body entirely.

description.text:
This is DOX - E3D inspiration Avatar robot from my recently built BigBox Dual machine. Pictured this when I focused on the X-carriage with its E3D V6 dual extruders and all that jazz cables imitating a big moustache face and the motors extruder pinion as balleyes from it's googles armatures. Foot print spells 'db' with a 'xo' within - alliteration of "big bOX" mirroring the "b" font - and there comes his name: DOX

Blender 2.57a files included - no subsurf modificators for precision edges observations.

Sliced on Simplify3D (fff: ABS 15%; extruder multiplier 2,1; skirt 4 outlines 0,8mm separation only for the lay down version; extruder temperature 230ºC/bed 120ºC; no cooling for ABS; default print speed 4000mm/min | outline underspeed 65% | solid infill underspeed 75%; gap fill overlap 40%).

Tested printed on 25% (25min), 50% (35min) and 100%(one hour).

print_settings.Notes:: IMPORTANT: I highly recommend to print each side standing up. You will surely find problems joining both sides if you decide to print them facing down.

description.text: I present to you the first 3d printed Super Nintendo cartridge. Super Nintendo has always been my passion since I was a little boy and making this project was a dream come true. That’s why I want to share this with you, so others with the same passion can enjoy and personalize it to create new and wacky designs. Thank you for downloading and please leave a comment if you have any suggestions.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

I3 Prusa Hephestos 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

You can check and see an example of the print settings I used for both sides in the image I uploaded.

IMPORTANT: I highly recommend to print each side standing up. You will surely find problems joining both sides if you decide to print them facing down.

Now that you have both sides printed...

Remove the support carefully and if posible wear protective eye gear to avoid any damage to your eyes. To join both sides you are going to need 3 allen screws.
-1 (M3 x 12) This one goes in the back.
-2 (M3 x 8) These go in the front.

Now you can open an original Super Nintendo Cartidge and transfer the chip to your newly printed cartridge. (You might need to file down some interior edges to create a better fit)

ENJOY!! :D

print_settings.Notes:: If you don't plan on illuminating the Opera House, feel free to use a normal infill percentage around 20%.

description.text:
First things first; attribution for the original design goes to user MiniWorld on pinshape.com. Unfortunately the model is not available on thingiverse, but you can check out the original model here.

The original model was modified as follows:
1) Scaled to 280%
2) The main buildings were entirely hollowed out (wall thickness about 3-5mm), while the bottom was filled in to create a flat surface.

We installed Adafruit NeoPixels in the box underneath and then printed the Opera House itself with eco3D PLA Light Diffusion Filament. This filament was designed to address the shortcomings of using transparent or natural PLA for lighting applications and does result in a smoothly illuminated Opera House.

Note that for lighting applications you should print with 100% infill (as any infill pattern will otherwise be visible through the illumination). This makes for a heavy print (about 10oz for the Opera House in the size as uploaded) and requires some good bed adhesion as even PLA has a tendency to warp and lift off the bed when you print large/thick solid surfaces.

For a detailed description of the project, including detailed instructions on how to install the Adafruit NeoPixels and what electronics supplies we used, check out our blog post "Sydney Opera House Illuminated with Adafruit NeoPixels"

This is a mod for the Ormerod 2 with a quickset hot end to use the dc42 Mini Differential IR Height Sensor instead of the stock sensor.
http://escher3d.com/pages/order/products/product1.php

2 parts are required.
The X Axis homing pad. The existing peg must be removed and the pad attached to the existing holes on the X motor bracket.

A new X Carriage with mounting holes for the sensor board.

Update: Alternate X Carriage added. This version is based on the 528.4 build and has a bearing that runs on the back of the x-arm rather than underneath.

There is little room between the sensor board and the Z axis rod so flat head or countersunk screws should be used to mount the board.

You may need to slow down the X-axis when homing. Edit homeall.g and homex.g Change the F3000 in the move command to F1000 for more reliable triggering.

description.text:
First, thank you Daniel for this amazing work.
I'll try to modestly contribute to this project, beginning with this remix of the round tower.

Extended and enlarged gate.
4 windows on the first floor.
A second floor with removable roof platform.

OpenSCAD code (Add in castle-kit-1-8.scad & doblo-factory-1-11.scad needed) :


module tower_round_2 ()
{
    $fs = 0.1;
    $fa = 4;
    // Size of lego's caracters : 50mm/3.2mm = 15.625
    solc = 15;
    //          (col, row, up, width,length,height,nibbles_on_off) 

    base_plate  (-4, -4, 0, 8, 8, 1, false);
    nibbles (-4, -1, 1, 8, 2);
    nibbles (-2, -2, 1, 4, 1);
    nibbles (-2,  1, 1, 4, 1);
    nibbles (-4, -4, 1, 1, 1);
    nibbles (-4,  3, 1, 1, 1);
    nibbles ( 3,  3, 1, 1, 1);
    nibbles ( 3, -4, 1, 1, 1);

    difference () {
    // tower structure
    union () {
        difference () {
        cyl_block (-4, -4, 1, 8, 8, 46, false) ;
        // carve it out
        cyl_block (-3, -3, 0, 6, 6, 48, false) ;
        // holes in the wall on top
        block (-6, -1, 42, 10,  2, 8, false) ;
        block (-1, -6, 42,  2, 10, 8, false) ;
        }
        // platform on middle
        difference () {
        cyl_block (-3, -3, 13.00, 6, 6, 6, false) ;
        cyl_block (-3, -3, 12.99, 6, 1, 5, false) ;
        }
        nibbles (-2, -2, 19, 4, 4);
        nibbles (-1, -3, 19, 2, 1);
        nibbles (-1,  2, 19, 2, 1);
        nibbles ( 2, -1, 19, 1, 2);
        nibbles (-1,  2, 19, 2, 1);
        nibbles (-3, -1, 19, 1, 2);
        // block for platform on top
        difference () {
        cyl_block (-3, -3, 29.00, 6, 6, 8, false) ;
        cyl_block (-3, -3, 28.99, 6, 5, 9, false) ;
        }
        // platform on top
        translate ([0,60,0]) {
        cyl_block (-2.95, -2.95, 0, 5.9, 5.9, 1,   false) ;
        nibbles (-2, -2, 1, 4, 4);
        nibbles (-1, -3, 1, 2, 1);
        nibbles (-1,  2, 1, 2, 1);
        nibbles ( 2, -1, 1, 1, 2);
        nibbles (-1,  2, 1, 2, 1);
        nibbles (-3, -1, 1, 1, 2);
        };

    }
    // doors, uses a "house form"
    house_lr   (-5, -1.5, 0, 10, 3, 13) ;
    // windows
    house_fb   (-0.60, -5, 23,  1.2, 10, 6) ;
    house_lr   (-5, -0.60, 23,  10, 1.2, 6) ;
    }
}

PS : It's my first experience on OpenSCAD so the code can probably be improve.

title: Slim C64 user port cartridge case

description.text:
A slim case for a module you built to Commodore 64's user port connector. In my case, I put to the case (besides the connector) a ESP8266 MCU+WiFi module. With the firmware I made it can be used to create telnet connections over Internet with old serial terminal programs to some BBSes and MUDs that still are used.

The case has a hole that can be used for a cable, LED, switch. Colorless plastic is nice to see through LEDs on PCBs. The lid part is actually a bottom cover which snaps in place because it is slightly tight. A standard user port connector can be screwed through the screw holes from inside the case to the plastic of the holes in the connector. The case parts have also texts "THIS SIDE UP" and "THIS SIDE DOWN", because great harm and smoke can occur if inserting a user port cart upside down.

Firmware:https://github.com/jsalin/esp8266_modem

Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oiP5Clx3D_s

comments.text: Hi, is there also a "normal size" cardridge? I would need the full size.
comments.author: Funkenspotz

comments.text:
For screwing the userport connector in, do you screw into the plastic or are there holes for threaded inserts?
Can you show a picture of an assembled one?
comments.author: Pyrofer

comments.text: Hi! I used two screws that go to the actual connector's holes firmly. They go through the holes of the 3D model, which are larger. The screws are actually thread from inside of the case outwards to the connector. This way the top of the screw does not block the connector from being pushed all the way in to the C64 because the top of the screw is inside the case. I would recommend first obtaining a connector and printing the case, and then selecting screws by good length and thickness based on your connector in practice or with help of a caliper.

print_settings.Printer:: R1 ABS + PLA Model

description.text:
Here's my rendition of a 3D printed drill angle/alignment press for 4x (3.5”) or 6x (5.5”) material at either a 45 or 90. Only 3 parts need to be bought: brass or bronze bushing (.500id x .750od x .500 long overall w/1.00x.125 deep flange...included in length), Harbor Freight drill chuck #45731, and a ½ x 20 x 1.5 bolt...if you use a coupon for the chuck you can come in at under 10.00 for all the stuff, I was going on the cheap here.

I added some pics for assembly reference...

The purchased items assemble in the “chuck holder”. The chuck holder is assembled to the “chuck mount pad” with the “holder” and “holder keeper”. This is the upper portion. Depending on manufacturing tolerances of the chuck, bolt, and bushing you may want to pick up some small thin washers to put in the end of the chuck where the ½ 20 bolt threads in, this may help with the preload on the chuck holder.

There's a little more going on with the lower portion. The base plate is setup for 90 and 45 holes and has clamp tabs. The tabs are .080 thick so with a 1mm top and bottom layer these should be solid with no infill. I went fillet happy with the model, it adds strength and seems to make the tool path easier as it limits abrupt changes in direction.

There are many varieties of guide rods: 90s, 45s, 4x material, 6x material, over-sized. “os” at the end of the file name means that it will allow for material that is .125 over the standard dimension...so they bump the width to 3.625; there are no over-sized rods for the 6x material as they use the “os” base “extension”. For the “os” files I included shims of .03125 and .0625 thickness to make up any difference. The “4x” or “6x” in the file name means those were made for the respective width. The 4x are longer and go past the base plate to align it to the material, the 6x just sit on top of the material as the base extensions are used for the alignment. The “c3.1” etc refers to the length and pairing so c3.1 and c1.3 are one side, with the first larger number being the longer one. I also made a rod clamp to use for clamping the rods to the material.

The springs have a large and a small end. The large end goes in the base plate. I also made some spring risers if needed. There are also angled spring risers when using the 45* setup.

With the exception of the spring risers and the over-sided rods this should be a no-support part. I made the tolerances on the tight side so some edges may need to be knocked down, etc.

All being said this is a pretty accurate setup, as you can see I went through lots of test parts to make sure everything fit the way I wanted to perform properly. I've included some small test parts to verify the tolerances before a commitment to print this...it's long. The parts are a rod section, the top holder and bottom base. The rod (fillet side up) should be a tight fit in the base and the holder should be a hard slip fit, it will slide a lot better when it “wears” a bit, some light grease helps as well.

Also, if any body has a good reliable model for a hex-shank drill chuck let me know, I'd like to redesign the chuck holder for one of those...

Although this is a legit model in it's current form I'm still going to tweak it like adding rack and pinion slides for the extensions and pivoting arms for multiple angles with one setup, maybe other stuff as it comes to me...

If anything else comes to mind I'll add it here...

Any comments, suggestions, ideas...totally open to them. If any solid model files are wanted let me know and I'll post them up...

description.text:
I saw that you "can" purchase a Tom's Aqua Lifter Holder / Bracket on many sites. But since I owned a 3d printer and I needed to figure out how to start modelling simple objects I thought what a nice little project.

This is a 7.62 x 39mm round.  This is NOT my design (downloaded from a 3D CAD resource on the net with no designer's name).
I wanted to print it out to test the Thing-O-Matic's ability to print objects that are much taller than they are wide or deep.  I printed it with a raft, no support, 20% infill (mainly for weight than stength), and 2 shell layers.
The print went very well, up until about the end of the "casing" section.  Since I designed my filament guide, I don't have to baby-sit my TOM nearly as much...so I let the print run while I ate dinner.  I visit to my upstairs office found that the base of the bullet was rocking back and forth, fore and aft during the print.  My nozzle seemed extra close to the printing object, which caused drag and probably caused this error.
Anyhow, this object printed just about how I expected.  The TOM shakes about quite a bit, and I wondered how well it would do with tall, narrow objects like this.  ANSWER:  Not very well.
I'm relatively new to the MakerBot scene (had mine almost a month now), but very familiar with CAD and CNC.  My belief is that objects such as this (if not all objects) should be printed with a moving extruder, not a moving build platform.  (I could be wrong... I was once before, back when I believed I was mistaken... heh heh.)

Print (at your own risk) with your own settings, and see what you can do with it.  Please note that my print was NOT successful.  I have no further ambitions with this design, other to mark it up as a learning process (i.e. "do not print tall, skinny things").
Please note that the STL file name is wrong... on my SD card, it was "7.62..." not "62..."  No, I'm not an idiot.  :)  I did my time as a Marine infantryman, and I definitely know my weapons & rounds.  This is NOT a 62mm round!  :)
Best of luck!  :)

comments.text: Yeah the comment was intended for anyone who is struggling with skinny and tall prints as they can be really challenging. I just looked at your makes, you have some really nice prints. I have a couple printers myself, a Prusa i3 clone and the Aluminum UM2 Clone frome here on Thingiverse. Thanks for sharing your work.
comments.author: SK-Polymer

comments.text: I notice that the top / pointed end of the bullet that some of the people here printed looks slightly warped. When the print gets smaller, there is less time for the previous layer of filament to cool, causing the layers to squish slightly. What I would do is #1 Make sure you have a layer cooling fan installed and working (if printing with PLA) #2 Increase Minimum Layer Time and #3 Either print two of the bullets ,at the same time, spaced a few inches apart from each other on the build plate. I have also created a simple shape, like a hollow tube, that is the same height as the bullet. The reason I believe this is a heat related issue is because the base of the bullet looks good. This could also be why it looks like you had a layer shift towards the top of the print.

comments.text: I'm not trying to be negative here but I thought I should provide some correction on the information provided here. The 7.62 x 39 is not the .308 caliber nor the standard NATO round. It's actually a russian cartrage from the 1940's. The NATO 30 cal round is the 7.62 x 51mm, which is also the .308 in USA. The 7.62 x 51mm is somewhat longer than the russian round and has a higher pressure/ muzzle velocity. I use the 7.62 x 51mm military surplus ammo frequently in me .308 for cheap target shooting.

Temp in the room was 2-3* F cooler than normal and I got to ~35 mm tall before I got a glitch and around 40mm before it started looking a little ugly.   Will allowing the "cool" to last longer help prevent the upper layers from "swelling" into the head?  I've only been printing for a couple weeks so I'm still learning.

comments.text: On another 3D printer, I had great luck using the "cool" settings to allow time for the layer to cool. I was printing the "do nothing machine" and the pins were coming out ugly. I used skeinforge 39. The key settings in "cool" were "slow down" and "Minimum Layer Time (seconds):  5.0". Hope this helps.  :)

print_settings.Notes:: I used a 5/64" drill bit to pilot the holes for the steel rods before inserting them. Similarly I used a 1/8" drill bit to pilot the holes for the magnets before pushing them into place. Finally I used a ABS acetone mixture to glue all of the sections together.

description.text:
I wanted an appealing and safe way to store / transport my game set so I decided to use an existing commercial case and adapt it to my needs. you can find the case available from TableWar Designs.

The storage boards are designed to hold 9 tiles from the JAWong set: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:26979, Variations http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1132283 and other tiles compatible with JAWong's tile design. While it is possible for these boards to be used for tiles without the magnetic bases I have not tested it. The magnetic bases I used were Isolt's 18, 3mm spherical ball magnet design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1108968.

Magnets are embedded into the board to interact with at least 4 sides of each tiles magnetic base. This allows the tiles to remain secure during transport and prevents them from jostling free. The magnets are aligned at the center line of each tiles side and the configuration is only compatible with Islot's 18 magnet base design. The magnets embedded into the boards are 1/8" diameter rare earth and are also available from the TableWar Design site. Each board is designed for 25 of these magnets.

Due to the size of the boards I found it necessary to cut the model into 3 sections to make them more printable, however this weakened the longitudinal strength of the board once it was assembled. To compensate for this each board piece junction is designed with 2 1cm deep holes to to insert a nominal 2cm long 2mm diameter steel rod into before adhering the board together. The rods themselves were readily available from amazon and I cut them into the appropriate lengths.

This is made to fit the type of nightlight sold at Dollar Tree, which is probably a pretty common cheap nightlight available at other stores. It has a 4w bulb. I've heard that PLA melts next to bulbs but I haven't had any problems with this yet.

I had to use the world's worst slicing program, so I ended up building the supports myself. There are 2 versions, with and without supports.

This was printed with .2mm layer height but I recommend using something lower.

It's a trading card deck separator to distinguish between decks when putting a lot of cards into a card box.  
Untested on regular card boxes so far, but can modify it to fit if I get the dimensions of a typical Weiss Schwarz card box.
I printed it with .35mm and it printed in 2 layers. I can print up to 2 sleeves on one print bed.

comments.text: if the cards are the same size as mtg cards then it should work fine even with the smaller yugioh cards
comments.author: Leonesshadow

author: bozkurt

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/5FV3HSQYuAr

Print in ABS, 100% infill

Keep and reuse the wheels from your broken dishwasher-slide bracket.

I used a brim and support. When the print is complete, find some 3mm or 1/8" nuts and bolts to attach the wheels. Use whatever bolts you can find to attach the two halves together.

The thing will shrink a little so the holes will be too tight, drill out the holes to suit your bolts.

To embed the nuts, pull out any brim from the hex-recesses, heat the nut an a gas flame and press it into the part. Or use a soldering iron to gently press it in. (Don't press too hard because you could crack your soldering-iron heater)

Brass bolts are a good choice. I used zinc coated, but they will eventually rust. You could cut any extra length using a small hacksaw but note that zinc-coated bolts will then have exposed steel and will obviously rust unless you coat the end.

If you are worried about using ABS in the dishwasher as it's not food safe, consider coating it. Someone suggested Plasti Dip. Check out this link for more information in general: https://all3dp.com/food-safe-3d-printing-material-filament-plastic/

So far, I've done 5 full washes and no issues with the print.

author: fdoffin

description.text:
Remix of Physics_Dude's low-poly fennec fox in Meshmixer so it had a Voronoi style to it. I remeshed the ears, feet and legs so it would pattern better in MM. I also flattened the bottom of the feet so the print should be more stable after it's completed. The mesh was fully repaired to remove any manifold issues after the Voronoi pattern was generated.

This guy will definitely need to be printed with supports, so I'd really only recommend this for a dual head printer so that the supports can be printed with PVA or some other dissolve-able filament. It will be very difficult to get the supports out of the final print if they are the same material as the model. I attached an image with supports generated in Simplify3D so you'll have an idea of what the support structure will look like.

author: Tumtum2814

description.text:
So, I designed and made this ornament for a contest at my local 3D-printing group meeting last month (and won an MBI Dynamo kit!).  
Christmas is unfortunately over for this season, but thought I'd share it with the world anyway.
Note: of the 4 top/bottom pieces, the two taller ones are both for the top.  You should be able to tell the orientation by looking at the curvature.

• print 2 of the "cage" and 1 of the "top bottom"
  • print diamonds to the scale that makes you happy
  • snap all cage pieces to the large piece of top/bottom except for 2
  • insert diamonds, arrange, and glue together. Plastic cement works well.
  • assemble final 2 cage pieces. add glue as necessary.
  • insert your hanging method of choice in the top hole. I used a metal wire.
  • enjoy!

description.text:
Cali Cat is designed to be the purrfect initial calibration and benchmarking print. It is a simple, standard test to ensure you have the basics down before proceeding to advanced prints. Cali Cat is the alternative to boring calibration cubes. It's a test print you can enjoy keeping. It consists of linear dimensioning tests of a calibration cube and more:

Linear dimensioning: Body 20x20mm, Height: 35mm, Tail 5x5mm
Inclines and overhangs: 45º

Prints in under 1 hour.
Calibrate your printer and grow an army of cats in the process!


Compare your print results with these two great resources for tweaking tips:

https://www.simplify3d.com/support/print-quality-troubleshooting/

http://support.3dverkstan.se/article/23-a-visual-ultimaker-troubleshooting-guide

comments.text: Congrats on the 3d printer. Getting nice overhangs has a lot to do with a mixture of speed and having good cooling. You want the previous layer to be cool enough so it maintains its position so the next layer has a rigid structure to lay on top. You'll have an wonderful time once everything is dialed in.
comments.author: ericje

comments.text:
Thanks!
I know, the Tarantula does not come with part cooling out-of-the box. So I ordered a fan already, and will print a duct for part cooling soon.
This will take some time to arrive, though. But really happy with the results so far. Nice, smooth straight walls, and the dimensions are within 0.05mm now, after two iterations of X-, and Y-steps corrections. So, once the fan is installed, I'll start playing with temps and speeds, and eventually with different materials.

comments.text: I've sliced it in S3D and printed it twice with different filament. Both prints have the same look - uneven edges, visible layers and distorsions - all the same on both cats. So I guess it's more a problem of the gcode than a problem of the printer. Right?
comments.author: Eddy_Vanderhellen

comments.text: G-code is just giving your printer directions and commands. It's more likely you need to adjust your printer settings (within the slicer) or minor mechanical things such as tightening belts. Also, it's not odd that different filaments brands and even just different color would need different adjustments. S3D also has a nice visual guide on what you may try to tweak depending on the results of your prints: https://www.simplify3d.com/support/print-quality-troubleshooting/
comments.author: Eddy_Vanderhellen

comments.text: For PLA, a lot of times it's the need for proper active cooling of the layer properly sets so the next layer lays down properly and level.
comments.author: Lacey1417

comments.text: Hard to say without seeing the print. Maybe post a picture of the print. 45 degree overhang is a doable standard which usually means the printer needs a little bit of calibration. Without seeing the print I'd probably guess the most common problem is the layers hasn't cooled enough so the proceeding layer doesn't lay on top properly. Combination of things to try turn up the fan speed to cool the part, slow down the print speed, and/or adjust the temperature of the hot end.

comments.author: Dezign

comments.text: I don't personally have experience with the MP Select Plus. Perhaps there's an official/unofficial forum for your printer. ABS in general takes a bit more finessing than PLA. The one on the far left is definitely better. Note the changes every time you start a new calibration print and see if you're headed in the right direction and adjust accordingly. With ABS you can give it a try by printing with cooling fan totally off and see what happens. ABS also seems to print better with an enclosed printer. So maybe also try a makeshift tub over the entire printer or cardboard box surrounding it. I've also seen that many Monoprice printer owners make improvement parts on their printers, such as improved fan ducts that cool the part better than doesn't blow at the hot end as much. Again hopefully there's a forum for your specific printer and continue to play with different variables.

description.text:
This customizable PV Solar breaker box was designed to accommodate a standalone 100A breaker for connection between the solar battery bank and the AC inverter. This box is for indoor use only. It is not sealed or waterproof.

The OpenScad file is included.

Edit the variables at the top of the file to suit your needs.

OpenScad creates a warning that the case body is not manifold, but this is nothing to be concerned about. It is a warning for the power cable holes in the side of the box. The project prints fine. You can ignore the warning.

Be sure to download the Write.scad files as this project prints text on the breaker guard.

The files are included with this project or online at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16193
Many thanks to Thingiverse user HarlanDMii for creating this text module!

This project has 3 parts:

  • box body
  • box cover
  • breaker switch protection guard

Print info:

  • Use PLA or ABS.
  • Set infill = 20%
  • Set walls = 2
  • Set layers = 0.25
  • No supports
  • No rafts

Requirements:

  • (4) screws for cover plate install
  • (4) screws to attach the box to a solid surface

Printer:

ORDBot

No

No

0.25

20%

These are the STL Files for an RGB Arduino Clock I made. I included the wiring diagram and source code for the Arduino IDE. The clock is modular and prints in seven different pieces. The clock face was designed by one of my students.

The clock works as follows:

Blue - Hour hand
Red - Minute hand
Green - Second hand

Yellow - Minutes inbetween the five minute intervals

For convenience in setting the time, there are push button switches to advance the minutes and the hours.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mti-0LtVpao

Modifications

The male female connections came out pretty well for me when I printed the modular pieces. However, the end of the clock did not stay together as hoped. For that reason I used glue at the end of the modular piece, near the holes for the LED. I will work on creating some clasps so that the ends do not need to be glued.

The toy train was designed to be a simple design that brings back childhood memories of playing with toys and creating stories. The train measures 100 mm long and 50 mm wide. The wheels and axles were printed separately to maintain an overall high quality print. I did use supports in some areas using Simplify3D. This model can also be scaled down to 0.5 to print faster and more comfortably as shown in the pictures.

This is a submission to the E3D BigBox contest in May 2016.

Notes (5/11/16):
Regarding support material - I used supports on the bottom of the train as there is no material toward the front of the train meeting the print bed. The windows did not need support material as the bridging occurs over small distances of 10-20 mm. The arch in the conductor's compartment also makes it possible to print without support.

description.text: This is my blend for the M3D Spool Holder. This only holds smaller spools and I have linked the original Sources. If Printing on the M3D you must print individually (Full Print_Wont Fit on the bed) and also its better to print the axel in the Vertical Upright position (Although Mine printed Just fine as is). Low Fill/Medium Quality setting no support or raft I was able to print all three files in under 2.5 Hours. The mounted posistion takes much stress off the pulling/guide to the extruder motor (which us M3D users know is a weak tiny hunk of crap for a motor). This fixed the small amount of excess stress mine was getting under_extrusion from, its strange how just changing the position can take So much stress off the extruder and this fixed all my under-extrusion issues along with regular nozzle cleaning.

title: Board Game Currency/Point Markers (Inspired by Paradox)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I would like to credit Paradox by Zac Dortch available at http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/384458/paradox-doctor-who-derivative-of-rftg for the inspiration for these. I'm not claiming them as a derivative of his work as they are just numbered hexagons and they use no art from his game as requested in his license. Paradox is a print [on paper] and play card game based on Race for the Galaxy. I really enjoy the concept of print and play games but I can't stand playing with paper coins. This is a simple 3d printable replacement for the paper point markers in this game or any other game. Note that despite looking blank in the thumbnails, these have their values carved in them. They are upside down in the CAD files so that they print number side down as I was getting better quality that way. I'm not sure why I put the smallest font on the largest marker but I've decided to stick with that choice. Since I've never played a game that uses the 3 chips I didn't feel the need to print them. They have therefore never been test printed.

The official instructions for Paradox state that you need:
"45 â€” Victory Point (VP) chips: [email protected], [email protected], and [email protected]" I just used skeinforge's multiply to make these into a sheet instead of preparing a plate. Don't forget to spray paint them Tardis blue.

If printing, then try to print it standing sideways as it will make the side clips stronger that way. I currently use the two halves separately to store two decks with an open top instead as I can't use it as intended. Took me about 7 hours to print on a Reprap i3 Prusa. author: huntley

description.text: I continue to explore tubular organic shapes with freely moving balls inside. This time I used a CAD program (Cheetah3D) to create a closed spline shape and then swept it with a circle. This way I created an organic shape with a constant diameter. I then opened this shape in ZBrush and used it as the basis for the design. Essentially this swept spline becomes the inside of the tube in the final design. Because it was created with a constant diameter circle, the balls will roll freely inside. See the descriptions for my other things for my design process or leave me a note and I will explain in more detail. I've added a short video to the Downloads showing this thing being rotated and the balls rolling inside or it can be viewed here: https://vimeo.com/75143117

I used ReplicatorG to prepare the file, a MakerBot Replicator2 with the Replicator 2 slicing defaults and the following settings with white MakerBot PLA to do the printing: Infill = 10%
Layer Height = 0.200
Shells = 1
Feedrate = 40
Travel Feed = 55
Temperature = 220 I used a raft with full support. It took over 19 hours to print with a length of 150 mm. Then it took several more hours to remove the support structure. Be patient and careful while doing this as the design is complex. Also it is tricky cleaning up the support structure from the balls once they are free to move.

author: wrusman

description.text:
These are designed to work with 3/8" balls, 0.230" diameter carbon fiber rods, and cylindrical magnets which are 10mm in diameter and 15m high.

These can be printed with a layer height of 0.2mm or 0.1mm.
Use a shell thickness of 2mm, so that all of the walls will be printed with concentric circles, instead of back-and-forth infill.
For PLA, use a relatively low temperature, like 185C, so that the overhang inside of the ball bearing sockets comes out as cleanly as possible.
I use a 3/8" ball end mill to gently clean out the ball bearing sockets.
Note: I have to print out at least two of these at a time, to get the correct dimensions. I usually print out a dozen of the ball bearing holders, followed by another of the rod ends -- ie. I usually don't mix them in one print run.
I use these with my magnetic effector: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1546124
And magnetic carriages: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1546091
Contact [email protected] if you need an inexpensive source for the ball studs or magnets.
I offer the ball studs for $1 each (12 are needed), and the magnets are $2 each (and I include printed and slightly machined rod ends with the magnets).

Printer:

Kossel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 to 0.1mm

Infill:

concentric circles

Notes:

These are designed to work with 3/8" balls, 0.230" diameter carbon fiber rods, and cylindrical magnets which are 10mm in diameter and 15m high.

These can be printed with a layer height of 0.2mm or 0.1mm.
Use a shell thickness of 2mm, so that all of the walls will be printed with concentric circles, instead of back-and-forth infill.
For PLA, use a relatively low temperature, like 185C, so that the overhang inside of the ball bearing sockets comes out as cleanly as possible.

I use a 3/8" ball end mill to gently clean out the ball bearing sockets.

  • 12 ball studs (you can make your own if necessary).
  • 12 10mm diameter, 15mm high N50 magnets.
  • 12 0.230" diameter carbon fiber tubes.
  • at least two 3/8" diameter ball bearings.
  • super glue and/or epoxy.

Also, I offer assembled printer arms using these in standard lengths of 215mm (Kossel Mini), 288mm (full-sized Kossel), and 304mm for $60/set. They're individually measured and marked, and within a set all of the arms match to within 50µm or less. Each individual joint is tested to have a minimum of 1kg of holding power.

This is a simple carriage which works with magnetic ball joints and Delrin or POM wheels on 1515 extrusions. You can get the wheels inexpensively from DeltaPrintr.com

This works nicely with my magnetic effector: https://www.youmagine.com/designs/kossel-plus-magnetic-effector

And with my magnetic ball joint rod ends:
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/magnetic-ball-joint-rod-ends

It is based on my more universal Kossel carriage:
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/improved-kossel-carriage-for-deltaprintr-or-graber-wheels-and-1515...

Contact me at [email protected] if you need an inexpensive source for the ball studs ($1) and/or magnets ($2). I also build carbon fiber arms in standard lengths of 215mm, 288mm, and 304mm and a set of 6 (with the 12 ball studs) is $60.

Materials and methods

Deltaprintr sells 9 carriage wheels with bearings for $20: http://deltaprintr.com/shop/hardware/carriage-wheel/

You will also need the usual M3 bolts, washers and nuts:

  • 3 M3x25 bolts for the axles.
  • 3 M3 washers as spacers.
  • 3 M3 nyloc nuts to hold the wheels on.
  • 1 M3x35 bolt for pretensioning.
  • 1 M3 nyloc nut for pretensioning.
  • 2 ball studs.
  • 2 M3 nylock nuts to hold the ball studs on.

Contact me if you need an inexpensive source for the ball studs. I had a bunch custom fabricated. 1000 were essentially the same price as 50, so I have lots left over to share with the Delta/Maker community! I'm offering them for $1 each, plus shipping. [email protected]

Aug. 2, 2016: Modified the carriage to add a place to attach a string, so that you can use a string with a spring to act as a safety in case something happens and the magnetic joint separates. This can also be used to supplement the magnetic attraction.

March 2017: Added versions for 2020 carriages with Delrin wheels:
With larger wheels: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2183347
With mini V-wheels: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2183355

description.text:
A Voronoi style remix of yeoldebrian's Octopus! The mesh was reduced bit by bit, and patterned in Meshmixer to give it the Voronoi effect. The resulting mesh was cleaned up and repaired where it was needed, so no manifold errors will interfere with slicing and printing.

While his tentacles might print ok, his head definitely will need supports to print correctly. Due to the Voronoi pattern and hollow interior, I'd really only recommend this for a dual head printer so that the supports can be printed with PVA or some other dissolve-able filament. It will be very difficult to get the supports out of the final print if they are the same material as the model. I attached an image with supports generated in Simplify3D so you'll have an idea of what the support structure will look like.

Airwolf 3D

title: Spool spindles for use with 3x6x2mm bearings

description.text:
Large is aprox. 45mm in center dia
Basic is aprox. 21mm in center dia
Both have 2.5mm lips on the end to hold spool in place so the hole in your spools need to be at least 5mm larger than the center Dia.

Two spool spindles for filament .. both designed to use with a piece of 3 mm tubing, and 3mm(inner) x 6mm (outer) x 2mm (thick) bearings. (used a lot on RC aircraft)

both are design so no support or inner structure is needed, to save filament and print time. Smaller one is solid caps as it's a small enough bridge that most printers should have no issue. the larger one is designed with 4 legs on top which are arced so the printer can build out without issue.

my printer isn't larger enough (M3D printer) to print legs so I just cut some out of scrap plywood.

I did have to knife out the bearing openings a tad as my printer's backlash sucks.. should be close if using a better printer though.. might even have to pad a bit.

title: Magnetic Effector with 3 Fans and LED Light Ring for Kossel Plus

description.text:
This in an improvement on my previous Magnetic Effector. Its improvements are: it holds up to three 5015 centrifugal fans, a LED light ring and a z-probe. This provides plenty of cooling for printing PLA and a well-lit work area. There are versions for both E3D and J-Head hotends.

The E3D version was designed and tested to work with an E3D hotend or a Geeetech all-metal hotend.
The J-Head version has been tested to work with a Genuine J-Head hotend.
I use the z-probe temporarily for auto-calibration.
You might want to use these with my carriage designs.
If you need the ball studs, I had quite a few made, so I offer them for $1 each.
I also precisely build carbon fiber arms to work with these.

Requirements
  • Up to three 5015 centrifugal fans similar to these: http://www.ebay.com/itm/6-pcs-Brushless-DC-Cooling-Blower-Fan-5015B-12V-50x50x15mm-2-Wires/141324730524
  • An LED light ring, which has an outside diameter of 60mm and inside diameter of 50mm. There are many inexpensive ones on Amazon and eBay.
  • 6 ball studs (which I sell for $1 each, plus postage).
  • 6 M3 Nyloc nuts for the ball studs.
  • 2 M3x10 socket head cap screws and 2 M3 nuts.
  • an M3x25 socket head cap screw and M3 nut for each fan.
  • a small amount of tape, for shimming the hotend, to make it tight. Silicone glue or caulking, or rubber cement also works well.
  • a switch if you would like to use the z-probe. I only use the z-probe for auto-calibration and then I remove it.
  • a 30mm axial fan, if you are using a J-Head.

title: Adelaide Laser Cutter HBOT ( not AxiDraw )
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Don't forget to like, share, add your makes and remixes.

Some of the parts used
2 Nema 17 Stepper motors - http://amzn.to/2vmdNtv
2 - GT2 20 teeth pulley - http://amzn.to/2wjVYZ5
5m ( you'll use less ) GT2 belts - http://amzn.to/2vmVioq
8 - M5 Idler - http://amzn.to/2vmwZHt

Inspiration

The first thing i thought when i saw the AxiDraw was " I want that " but then after a few seconds i said " im building that ". I finished my design a couple of weeks after it was announced. Even though i have built my own CoreXY i could not get into my head the belt path. After some research and help from the community i got to the HBOT design.

From there was just figuring out how to build it with whatever i had left from other projects. I was stuck for a couple of days figuring out how to build it, since i did not want to use 2 plates to carry the linear bearing. Move this here, move this there until i hit the sweet spot.

Objective

Build a machine to be used with a laser diode to test LaserWeb, a very complete open source solution for Lasers ( cncpro.co ). Simple to print, easy to assemble and mostly inexpensive. Needed to be small and able to carry it around.

Sorry about the rust, but where i live even rust get rust

https://youtu.be/zJTmoou9EX8

Update: Im using LaserWeb4 with GRBL 1.1, you can find the firmware here https://github.com/cojarbi/grbl-servo-CoreXY

Printer:

Custom CoreXY

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

300 Micron

Infill:

30%

Notes:

No support needed.
I use a brim in every print i do.

Bellow you'll find a list for all the parts needed for this project. Im a regular amazon prime customer so i will link to them and as you'll see is just easy to source.

Electronics

  • 2 - Nema 17 stepmotors.
  • 1 - Controller board
    • Smoothie firmware based board > 32Bit boards highly recommended
      • AZSMZ. ( The one i use )
      • Azteeg X5.
      • Smoothieboard.
    • GRBL firmware based board.

Hardware

  • 1 Kit - GT2 timing belt with pulleys.
  • 1 Kit -Ball bushing linear motion ( only 4 needed ).
  • 4 - 8mm Linear shaft. This will determine the size of the machine. Mind that you will need to make sure the belt length is enough >
    • 330mm long.
    • 495mm Long.
  • 6 - 625 Bearing.
  • 4 - M5 x 25mm
  • 4 - M5 Nut
  • 4 - M3 x 20mm
  • 4 - M3 x 25mm
  • 4 - M3 x 10mm
  • 12 - M3 Nut
  • 4 - Washers
  • 4 - Shim
  • 10 - Zip ties small
  • 1 - Lead screw or similar + Nut and washers

Laser Module

  • L-Cheapo Laser Diode.

• If you have an AZSMZ board or smoothie ( changes would need to be made ) you can use the config.txt provided.
  • If you need help with GRBL drop request in the comment section and ill post my settings

title: 30mm to 40mm fan adapter - rotated 40mm fan to fit Toranado Extruder

description.text:
I printed a Toranado extruder for my 3d printer and I wanted quiet 40mm fan to cool the E3D V6 hot end instead of the very loud stock 30mm fan. I tried many of the existing ones on Thingiverse, but there were screw collision issues or thin wall issues on all I tried. So, I designed one with a slightly rotated 40mm fan. That let me easily get to all the holes for both the 30 and 40mm fans and still have good wall thickness.

The Toranado extruder doesn't allow for much extra width outside of the size of a 30mm fan, so the 30mm fan side has an outside dimension of 30x30mm.

I use this Noctua 40x10mm fan with my E3D. It's incredibly quiet and works great: http://amzn.to/24cGcb1

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

25%

Notes:

It needs supports for the underside of the 30m bolt holes. Other than that, just about any print settings should work. I printed mine in PETG at 0.28mm layer thickness, 4 bottom layers, 5 top layers and 3 perimeter layers.

A 1:24 Queen Anne Sofa to match the rest of the parlor set.  Three sizes provided.  These sofas are scale reproductions of 78", 66" and 54" sofas.
Building a Makerbot Playset?  Scale the sofas up by a factor of 1.5 to get them into 1:18 scale.

Print a "print plate" for your desired size, which includes the body of the sofa and the requisite number of legs.  Print without raft.  I used stock Print-o-matic settings on my TOM.
Or, add some color by printing the legs separately from the body.  Body and back legs print best without a raft.  Front and front center legs require a raft. Use the multiply setting in skeinforge to print more than one leg at a time.
Legs should pop easily into sofa body.  Add a drop or three of acetone for a permanent fit.

title: Deadpool Bust HD (With Supports)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Such a pain in the butt isn't it when you find a good 3D model to print only to find they just ripped the model from a game, made it solid and uploaded it. No work, nothing done to it to improve it at all - but they hooked you with a flashy screenshot that gave you a glimmer of hope for a few fleeting seconds between mouse clicks.

Every single... (edit) MOST deadpool model here on thingiverse is a game model rip. The model was ripped from the game and then uploaded to Tf3DM.com - and has been probably the most overly uploaded model I've seen.

As most people know the textures or bump maps that make a 3D model pretty in a game don't translate to the mesh itself, they are a graphic shader, tomfoolery meant to make us think a flat object has a bumped surface. Sadly you miss out on all that detail when you print the model. You just get the plain surface. Yes there is a way to convert bump maps and get them on the finished model (displacement maps) but at the time did not know how to make them.

So I wanted to take the game mesh and add the stitching detail on it which will help me when I paint it. It is a little hefty at 45mb, but really that's about as low as I could go with the stitching still in tact. The slices at the side are done at 50 degrees, so they really don't need any support.

I have meshmixed both and netfabbed them, supports are set at max 40 degrees, so they should be fine, but i've included the non-supported one if you want to generate your own.

I've included an image of the original game character model that I used for the base as a comparison.

The original game mesh was from tf3dm.com
http://tf3dm.com/3d-model/deadpool-42722.html

I did a simple remix of an iPhone 6 Plus case I like. I'm sure a design exactly like this must already exist somewhere on Thingiverse, but I haven't found it and I know at least one other person that would like a plain design like this. remixed_from.title: Flashforge Creator Pro Filament Alignment Bracket

title: Ultimate Filament Guide - Flashforge Creator Pro

description.text:
ULTIMATE FILAMENT GUIDE

  • For Flashforge Creator Pro (and similar compatible machines)

This design encompasses a dust filter system, as well as allowing your filament to go from the spool to the extruder virtually unexposed to air! Used in conjunction with a dry box (I use this one - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:743280), this will increase the life of your filament, and improve print quality by keeping the plastic fresh, and minimising defects during printing due to dust particles (sometime present prior to purchase). There's also a handy storage space for your allen keys!

This requires less than $10 of external parts, and prints easily using ABS. The dry box also cost less than $10 to build.

External parts required (all bought easily from eBay):

  • 6mm 1/8BSP Male Thread Quick Air Fitting Coupler Connectors: 4 required for this part, at least another 2 (recommended 4+) for your dry box.

  • 3mm PTFE teflon tubing: 2 lengths required, length will vary (distance to your dry box)

  • Kitchen sponge: 2x 1cm3 pieces.

The dust filters push into the main part by utilising two locking lugs - the can only turn one direction 180 degrees. There is a small amount of play when locked - this was to prevent them from breaking easily when twisting the connected tubing.

I have modified or redesigned a few other Thingiverse items to make my design (see remixed from section).

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.20

Notes:

  • Dust filters : Print at .20 or less to allow a good resolution on threads (slower is generally better). Print WITH supports recommended

  • Main body: Any layer height, your mileage may vary but I printed without supports fine.

Once main part is completed, push a male filter into each of the ports and twist 180 degrees (no more). This will hopefully clear out any sagging etc from the bridging.

Filter insertion: In each 1 cm3 cube of sponge, either poke a hole through with the filament in place, or cut a slice halfway through the sponge and wrap around the filament.

Suggestion: When putting the couplers into the lid of your dry box, ensure you don't put them in the centre - offset them to allow the filament to come off the spool as close to 90 deg as you can.

title: Riser. Filament Guide, Oiler Holder All in one for Maker Select Wanhao i3 v2

description.text: I needed to raise up my spool holder for a couple of slightly larger spools I also needed a guide and oiler holder so I designed one in tinkercad that did all 3.

Printer:

Maker Select (I3 V2)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

On my maker select I had simplify3d set to 1.00 and .65mm I increased the multiplier to 120% on the printer itself. it seemed to need it maybe it did not. Came out fine either way.

I guess you could print at 200mics but it was only an extra 40 minutes at 100mics and I like the nicer cleaner look of the higher resolution. I imagine it will work just fine at 200mics its a simple part.

If the oiler hole is not large enough its just plastic. use a pair of scissors to "ream" out the hole from both sides till its the side you need. Don't forget to clean up the bolt holes if it requires attention.

if the bolts try to thread in like they did for me just tighten then down (on the plastic only) and strip them. then attach to the printer.

I designed this in tinkercad. I took some measurements from the printer itself the bracket is roughly 50x60mm measure the width from outside bolt head to edge of bracket remove 50% of bolt width to get center of hole. same for side to side.

make holes a wee larger than you think you will need (plastic expands a little)

Added gussets for strength and aesthetics. rounded top for smoothness and strength.
